entry.title: Gold Stainless Steel Jewelry
entry.content:
Gold Stainless Steel Jewelry

The idea of gold stainless steel might sound a bit strange at first. It need not be. Gold stainless steel jewelry is simply stainless steel jewelry that has a thin layer of gold coating.

This process is often done using an electric current with a tub of gold solution. This process is commonly known as wet plating.

The layer of gold plating can be anywhere from 0.17 to 2.5 microns. A micron is equal to 0.0001 centimeters. The final color you get will vary in color depending on the purity of the gold used to do the plating.

When Plated Jewelry Is Ideal

Gold-plated jewelry often has a short lifespan, typically six months to a year. So to extend longevity, it's best to get gold stainless steel pieces for ornaments you do not wear often.

The reason for this is that gold-plated items have very little actual gold on them. This makes them more susceptible to tarnishing and fading. In addition, for metals that are not hypoallergenic, this can expose the wearer to skin irritation.

Stainless steel is hypoallergenic, so this is not something you need to worry about when wearing gold stainless steel.

Taking Care Of Your Gold Stainless Steel Ornaments

While you can get to enjoy your jewelry for about a year without it fading, this does not come without taking some precautions.

For starters, avoid wearing gold stainless steel with other items as these can rub against each other and damage the coating much faster. As much as possible, wear your plated stainless steel on its own.

Secondly, avoid water, chemicals, and make-up coming into direct contact with your plated items as much as possible. If you are a swimmer, for example, the chemicals in a pool can quickly corrode the coating. In such a case, it helps to take off this jewelry before taking a dip. If you forget to do so, ensure to rinse it with plain water as soon as possible and air dry it.

After you have worn your gold-plated stainless steel jewelry, ensure to wipe it down at the end of the day. Use a soft cloth to gently rub its surface up and down to pry away any dirt and debris it might have collected during wear.

If you need a more thorough clean, soak it in warm water and mild dishwashing soap solution. A 10-15 minute soak will loosen any dirt, sweat, and make-up from the jewelry’s surface. You can then gently wash it with a soft cloth and air dry it before putting it in storage.

Again, try and store gold stainless steel jewelry in individual cloth bags to prevent them from scratching each other and possibly getting damaged.

It might also help to take off your jewelry before hitting the gym or engaging in other activities that might cause you to sweat.

One Final Thing…

Aside from proper care, a sure way to ensure your jewelry remains in top shape for longer is by buying good quality, to begin with. By purchasing from a reputable dealer, you are certain that the jewelry was made under strict conditions to give you the quality you deserve.

entry.title: Can You Take a Shower With Stainless Steel Jewelry?
entry.content:
Can You Take a Shower With Stainless Steel Jewelry?

Stainless steel jewelry is a great option for many for numerous reasons. Key among them is that it's relatively affordable compared to gold, and it's very durable. Stainless steel jewelry also offers a clean, understated finish that can effortlessly go with anything in your wardrobe.

These are some of the qualities that have escalated its popularity in recent years.

However, once you get your jewelry, it's common to wonder about its care regimen and its limitations. For example, a common question asked regarding stainless steel jewelry is how it holds to water.

Does Stainless Steel Tarnish?

Before we get into how your stainless steel jewelry will handle water, let’s talk about this metal Vis a Vis tarnishing.

Do stainless steel rings tarnish? What of other stainless steel jewelry items?

The answer to both these questions is no. Good quality stainless steel jewelry will not tarnish. However, you have to consider the grade of stainless steel you are getting before making a purchase. Lower grades can tarnish; good grade stainless steel will not.

The best quality stainless steel is 304, also referred to as 18/10/ or 18/8 respectively, to represent its composition. This means 18% Chromium and 10% Nickel or 18% Chromium and 8% Nickel. The other grade is 316.

Stainless steel also has 2% molybdenum. Molybdenum increases the metals’ resistance to corrosion and acids with chloride ions. This prevents it from rusting.

Can I shower With Stainless Steel Jewelry?

Yes, you can. You can safely shower with your stainless steel jewelry and wash your hands with a stainless steel ring without the ornaments getting any major damage.

While water might not cause any damage, harsh chemicals can. Mild shampoos and shower gels are fine, but if you have any corrosive hair chemicals and so on, it might be prudent to take the jewelry off. You can also be sure to rinse it and dry it off properly if you accidentally expose it to harsher chemicals.

What about water with different compositions?

Stainless Steel in Ocean Water

You already know the ocean is salty. What you probably don't know is that these levels of salt are not very kind to any metal, stainless steel included.

As gorgeous as your jewelry might be, do not wear it in the ocean. There are also other dissolved substances and inorganic materials that might damage your ornaments. The ocean also has sand that can scratch the jewelry's surface.

Stainless Steel in a Pool

Stainless steel with molybdenum offers some protection against acids and localized corrosion from chloride ions. If you are an active swimmer, it’s important to get jewelry with this compound.

However, you better off taking off your jewelry before diving into a pool to be on the safer side. If you forget to do this, rinse the piece with clean water as soon as possible, and air dry it.

 

Final Word

Here you have it. You can have your stainless steel jewelry from Monera in the shower without degrading it. However, take them off when in the ocean or the swimming pool.

entry.title: Some Facts On Stainless Steel Jewelry
entry.content:
Is Stainless Steel Jewelry Safe to Wear?

Stainless steel is made from at least 10.5% chromium and other alloying compounds. It also contains carbon in quantities of 1.2% or less. These alloying compounds include nickel, niobium, molybdenum, titanium and manganese.

Stainless steel was traditionally found in medical equipment. In recent times, this metal has found itself in jewelry-making for all the stellar qualities it is known to provide to medical equipment.

Is Stainless Steel Safe to Wear?

For the most part, yes. Medical grade stainless is extremely safe to wear on the skin. The only issue with stainless steel is the alloys used, their quality and their quantities can cause problems to wearers.

One of the alloys that commonly cause problems is nickel. Nickel is affordable, making it the go-to alloy metal of choice for many jewelers. Unfortunately, many people have a sensitivity to this metal. This often happens when there is 100parts of nickel per million. However, in most countries, the amounts of nickel used in jewelry are highly regulated to ensure end-user safety.

This means that jewelry pieces carrying anything above the healthy amounts are not allowed to retail. 304 stainless steel and 316L surgical steel have extremely low Nickel levels and are often safe to wear even for individuals with a Nickel allergy to enjoy wearing occasionally.

305 stainless steel has 8% Nickel, compared to 10% in 316L Nickel, making it the safest of all stainless steel. 

How To Test Genuine Stainless Steel?

The easiest way to test stainless steel jewelry is using a magnet. Because steel is magnetic, your jewelry should attach to the magnet. If this does not happen, you do not have stainless steel.

The other test is rust. Properly processed stainless steel does not rust. If your jewelry begins showing signs of rust around the edges and whatnot, this might indicate what you have is not stainless steel.

The two final ones are the polish and the tap tests.

For the polish test, wipe the surface of your jewelry with a dry cloth and check to see if you can see your reflection. With stainless steel, you should be able to see your face. If you don't, you probably have a knock-off or other metal like aluminum.

The tap test, on the other hand, requires you to tap the surface of your jewelry with a brass key or a penny. A 'ting' sound indicates stainless steel, while a 'clang' indicates what you have is not actual stainless steel.

Advantages of Stainless Steel Jewelry

The first thing stainless steel has going for it is durability. Unlike some jewelry types that are extremely fragile and require to be worn with caution, stainless steel jewelry is sturdy enough to be worn by the most active people, with minimal damage.

 

The other is aesthetic value. The shine produced by stainless steel jewelry comes pretty close to that from sterling silver, often at a lower cost.

Lastly, this compound won’t rust or corrode. You can wear it comfortably in any climatic conditions without worrying about damaging it.

entry.title: Is Stainless Steel Jewelry Hypoallergenic?
entry.content:
Is Stainless Steel Jewelry Hypoallergenic?

When you have sensitive skin, taking care of yourself is quite challenging as you have to evaluate every item before you use it. Mainly, you are limited in the type of jewelry you can put on, as the direct contact of these fashion accessories often results in bad allergies. All the itching, red, and swollen skin is never pleasant, and you are always better off avoiding situations that lead to these problems. This brings us to the big question - can you wear stainless steel jewelry without it reacting with your sensitive skin?

A look at stainless steel jewelry and its formation

If you have sensitive skin, then the metals that primarily lead to an allergic reaction are nickel, copper, and zinc. Nickel is the worst of the three, as studies have shown that it is the most reactive to people with sensitive skin. This means that you always need to go for the nickel-free options whenever you are shopping for jewelry, as they are likely to be hypoallergenic. Sadly, nickel is widely used when making metal alloys, given its excellent properties since it hardens metals such as silver and gold.

When it comes to the formation of stainless steel, it is a similar scenario as the preferred metals for creating this alloy is nickel. Nevertheless, this metal compound is at times made of other metals such as chromium, titanium, carbon, and iron. In such cases, the stainless steel will have low or negligible nickel levels, making it have excellent hypoallergenic properties. This is why today, you find the term ‘nickel-free stainless steel’ is widely used when marketing stainless steel jewelry that does not contain any percentage of nickel.

Should I purchase stainless steel jewelry if I have sensitive skin?

The most straightforward answer to this question is –it depends.

You are probably wondering, what does it depend on? Well, firstly, you need to consider the type of stainless steel that the jewelry is made from. Secondly, you need to know how sensitive your skin is to metals used to make this alloy. If you are highly sensitive to even the lowest exposure of these metals, then you need to avoid any jewelry that contains any trace of these allergens.

Generally, the rule of thumb for anyone with sensitive skin is to settle for surgical-grade stainless steel alloys. The best grade widely used for making jewelry is the 316L stainless steel, as it is almost 100% free of nickel. This is a giant leap from most stainless steel grades that contain up to 10% nickel and would pose a severe risk if you have sensitive skin.

Why choose 316L stainless steel jewelry for sensitive skin

In the fashion industry, the 316L stainless steel is widely known as hypoallergenic stainless steel. The reason behind this is simple – this stainless steel alloy does not contain any metal that widely causes allergic reactions. All the metals used to make the 316L stainless steel, namely chromium and iron, are relatively stable and non-reactive. The best part is that this alloy does not rust even when exposed to damp environments, and you will never have to worry about it rusting over time.

entry.title: Which Is Better: Sterling Silver or Stainless Steel Jewelry?
entry.content:
Which Is Better: Sterling Silver or Stainless Steel Jewelry?

 

If you are a big fan of jewelry, you probably have had this debate in your head already. 

When it comes to jewelry, the great divide is about gold vs. silver. While being a silver lover edges you closer to your final choice,

You still need to choose between the two big wigs: sterling silver and stainless steel.

Which one of these is best?

Here, read more on what each is, the differences, and the best pick.

316L Stainless Steel vs. 925 Sterling Silver

These two metals confuse most people because they share a common physical property; both have a shiny, silvery finish. 

This aside, the two are very different. 

Stainless steel consists of iron and chromium. At times, there are traces of nickel. When oxygen mixes with chromium, a transparent film is formed. This film is what protects the steel from rusting. 

The steel used in making jewelry differs from the one used in construction and is also known as surgical stainless steel. The result is a durable, timeless, monochromatic look.  

Stainless Steel Jewelry Pros:

  • More affordable compared to sterling silver jewelry
  • Beautiful, mirror finish
  • Durable
  • Hard to dent
  • It does not rust, meaning its less likely to lose its glossy appearance

Stainless Steel Jewelry Cons:

  • It’s very hard, which also makes resizing difficult. 

Sterling silver is not pure silver, but silver with another metal.  

Sterling silver means 92.5 % of silver blended with a 7.5 % copper alloy. The number 925 or sterling is often stamped on jewelry to indicate that the piece is made of sterling silver.

Sterling Silver Jewelry Pros: 

  • It has an attractive, matte, classy finish
  • It can be molded easily, which explains the variety of designs jewelry creators can come up with
  • You can get stones included in it

Sterling Silver Jewelry Cons:

  • It tarnishes with time
  • it lacks the new jewelry look and shines
  • It can be dented
  • it’s often costlier than stainless steel

Which Is Best?

The stainless steel vs. sterling silver debate is unlikely to end any day soon. Often, it boils down to preference. 

There are, however, good reasons why stainless steel seems to be the preferred option for most customers.  

Its shiny look, affordability, and easy to clean properties make stainless steel jewelry very appealing.

The other significant deciding factor is that stainless steel is hypoallergenic. Wearers enjoy the freedom that comes with wearing their jewelry without the risk of skin irritation. Stainless steel jewelry allows you to enjoy your pieces year-round, safely.

The third is that it’s extremely easy to maintain. A quick wash with warm soapy water and a firm polish is all you need to keep your jewelry looking brand new.

As you vet jewelers, also look at the mode of payment they provide. You want to pick a company with as many various options as possible because then you are unlikely to get stuck while trying to make payments.

6. Take Your Time
As eager as you might be to get your jewelry shop up and running, you should take the time to think through and thoroughly research your supplier choice.

entry.title: How to Clean Stainless Steel Jewelry ?
entry.content:
When looking at how to clean stainless steel jewelry, you find there is some great advice out there.  Stainless steel jewelry is actually really very rugged and can be cleaned in a variety of ways.  When you are preparing to clean your stainless steel jewelry be sure to take the jewelry off.  This will allow you to get at it better but also protects your skin from the substances that you are using to clean it with.  There are a lot of great benefits to wearing and having stainless steel jewelry such as it is one of the best materials for those that have allergies to the various metals. 

When looking up how to clean stainless steel jewelry you need to keep in mind that this metal is also very hard.  This means that it is not easily scratched or ruined by abrasive cleaners.  However, we don't recommend abrasive cleaners, unless you absolutely need them.  Most of the time when you are cleaning stainless steel jewelry you are simply looking to clean off the dirt and grime that comes with wearing the jewelry, or you might be looking to clean it after it has been sitting awhile. Neither of these options will require abrasive cleaners. 

Stainless steel doesn't tarnish.

Another amazing trait of stainless steel jewelry is the fact that it doesn't tarnish or rust.  This allows for this type of jewelry to be worn at all times and it really doesn't need to be removed while swimming or showering either.  You should remove your jewelry at all times when you are doing crafting or things that might get paint or other substances on the jewelry to simply protect it.  Like your clothing, your jewelry needs to be protected during certain activities.  

If you are looking for an inexpensive way to clean your stainless steel jewelry, we would recommend getting some baking soda.  Baking soda is great for capturing odors in your fridge and it acts well as a cleaner as well.  All you need is an inexpensive box of baking soda and water to get the job done.  Mix the water and baking soda together to form a bit of a paste.  You can simply use your hands to rub it onto the jewelry but some prefer to use an old toothbrush. 

Scrub the jewelry gently until clean.  Once clean, simply rinse the piece of jewelry underwater to rinse away any remaining baking soda.  You can then wipe the jewelry off with a soft towel or napkin to remove any access water.  Be sure to lay it out to dry as well.  This will ensure that all the extra water is gone before putting it away.

Stainless Steel Jewelry Cleaning Kits

If you want to get a little fancier, there are some stainless steel jewelry cleaning kits out there as well.  This allows you to clean the jewelry a little more in-depth.  However, these kits look fancy, they really do about the same job as the baking soda method.  Some will come with a polishing cloth that works basically in the same way as the cloth above as well.

When you are looking to clean your stainless steel jewelry, keep in mind that you are working with one of the hardest metals in which jewelry is made from.  This allows you a little more leeway on what substances you use to clean the metal.  You can also simply use commonly found household cleaning substances as well.  Cleaning your jewelry with a window cleaner or glass cleaner, for example, would be a fine option as well.  Vinegar is also another cleaner that many uses to clean their stainless steel jewelry too.  

An ultrasonic jewelry cleaner might be just the thing if your stainless steel jewelry is very intricate.  This is a machine that is made to clean jewelry.  The solution that you choose to use in the machine can be made for ultrasonic jewelry cleaners or you can simply use glass cleaner.  This is a very effective way to get down in the cracks and rhinestones should you have more details.

Common household items to clean stainless steel.

Another great way to clean stainless steel jewelry is with toothpaste.  The mild abrasion is okay for your enamel.  This means that it is not super abrasive but very effective.  To clean, simply rub the toothpaste on the item with either your fingers or a toothbrush.  Rinse when done and pat dry.  Before putting the jewelry back on, you will need to let it sit out for a bit to completely dry.  

For a higher polish to your stainless steel jewelry, you can use a polishing cloth that will help bring out the shine in the jewelry piece.
